report_title: Industry Report on Corporate Wellness Services
executive_summary: Corporate wellness services sell products like Health Risk Assessments (HRAs), weight management, health education, stress management and other services. The industry is characterized by a small number of similarly sized large operators and large research spending, though market share concentration is low. Revenue has slumped over the past five years as economic disruptions have shaken downstream demand. The COVID-19 pandemic caused governments to shut down businesses, which dragged down corporate profit and encouraged businesses to cut their expenditure on discretionary services, like corporate wellness products. As the economy opened up, employment surged, increasing demand for the industry's services. current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The onset of the pandemic caused state and local governments to shut down businesses, resulting in a major drop in corporate profit and consumer spending.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Poor business performance meant companies didn't make risky investments in 2020, including in corporate wellness services.
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Downstream demand from corporations plunged during the pandemic, revenue for the industry took a big hit.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The industry's revenue is expected to slump.
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Still, rising inflation has caused households to take on more debt, worsening the mental health of the population and boosting demand for the industry's services. Overall, revenue for corporate wellness service companies has been declining at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 0.8% to an estimated $19.8 billion over the five years through 2023, in spite of a 3.4% rise in 2023 alone.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The industry is expected to perform much better in the next few years.
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As concerns regarding COVID-19, high inflation, elevated interest rates and recessionary fears subside, investor uncertainty will decline and companies will be better able to make more long-term investments and spend more on corporate wellness services.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: As food remains unhealthy and Americans stay sedentary, obesity is anticipated to increase modestly during the outlook period.
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Companies will be enticed to invest more in weight management services to keep their healthcare costs down, which will boost revenue for the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Advancements in software will make health risk assessments (HRAs) and weight management services less expensive and more accessible, creating new revenue streams for corporate wellness service companies.
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Value-added innovations will boost prices, lifting profit. In contrast, these advancements will enable corporations to provide corporate wellness services in-house, potentially threatening the industry's performance.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Overall, revenue for corporate wellness services is forecast to creep upward at a CAGR of 0.8% to an estimated $20.7 billion over the next five years.
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The nation's labor force has expanded in the wake of the pandemic, causing more companies to pay attention to their workers. Demand for corporate wellness services has risen, bringing back revenue growth for corporate wellness service companies.

industry_definition: This industry includes companies that primarily provide workplace programs that offer a combination of educational, organizational and environmental activities designed to support behavior that is conducive to the health of employees and their families. This doesn't include programs designed internally by existing human resources personnel.
key_trends: The industry performed poorly during the current period, mostly because of a major decline in revenue during COVID-19. Greater employment amid the recovery and more household debt brought back some growth for corporate wellness services, though.

Spending on corporate wellness services will expand during the outlook period, especially amid returning investor confidence, solid innovation and higher obesity rates. The increasing prevalence of substitutes may threaten revenue during this period, though.

Most of the regulations that impact corporate wellness service companies relate to the collection of information. Operators must ensure the privacy of the health information of their customers because of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPPA). Companies also faced new regulations at the start of the pandemic.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Companies in the health and education sector that buy from corporate wellness providers include tutoring companies, charter schools, social assistance companies, hospitals and other organizations.
Manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers require workers with more skills, so there's less turnover in these industries, creating more investment in corporate wellness services.

Arts and entertainment companies include movie theaters, music halls, art galleries and other places to engage in fun activities. Since many of these organizations have employees that stay for a long period of time, demand for corporate wellness services is high in this sector.

Financial and information (e.g., market research, data analysis) companies have highly skilled and well-paid workers that demand benefits, so this sector spends heavily on corporate wellness services.
Manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers require workers with more skills, so there's less turnover in these industries, creating more investment in corporate wellness services.
Government organizations and agencies provide an important stream of revenue for the industry, as high unionization and commitment from employees creates demand for corporate wellness services.

Farms hire agricultural and service workers that aid in food and cash crop production. Since many of these employees are temporary, farms often don't invest in corporate wellness services, so agriculture represents a small portion of revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: HRAs are questionnaires that corporate wellness companies give out to receive information about their employees' nutrition, height, weight, physical activity, stress levels, smoking history and other health metrics.
Mental health services include discounts on therapy, in-office stress management programs and help in reducing distractions when working from home.
Other programs provided by corporate wellness service providers include health education, music therapy, yoga, Tai Chi, lactation (breastfeeding) support and a slew of other programs.
Nutrition and weight management services include seminars, conferences and workshops that educate employees on nutrition habits and incentives that encourage more physical activity.
Fitness services provide in-house gyms or pay for gym memberships for their employees.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: As more businesses pop up, they'll seek corporate wellness services since many companies think they're essential for employees, benefiting the industry.

As the number of employees in the United States rises, more businesses may offer employer-mandated health insurance. Many employers will proceed to purchase corporate wellness services to help bolster productivity and lower employee absenteeism, among other benefits.

The adult obesity rate index measures the percentage of United States citizens with a body-mass index of more than 30 points. As the frequency of obesity and subsequent health challenges surge, more businesses may purchase corporate wellness programs that offer services such as nutritional counseling and healthy cooking classes.

Employees without the financial ability to make long-term investments in their own health are more likely to demand employee-offered health plans and benefits. Financial struggles exacerbate issues of stress and mental health, so more debt owed by households should benefit the industry.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Number of People with Private Health Insurance
demand_determinants.determinant_description: A rising number of individuals with private health insurance may be indicative of more people having employer-mandated health insurance. As more employees have employer-mandated health insurance, some businesses may purchase corporate wellness services to help lower healthcare costs.

While recreation itself is an essential part of an individual's holistic health, high recreation spending is typically associated with an increase in indulgent consumption of less healthy options. Individuals with high recreation spending are also far more likely than average to hold jobs at companies where industry wellness services are offered.

Corporate investment in wellness programs is a long-term bet for the purchasing company. Not only do some health plans take years to return significant financial gains, but a shakeup in the labor market can incentivize employees in corporate wellness programs to take their increased productivity elsewhere. When investor uncertainty increases, companies are more hesitant to undertake long-term investments.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE HEALTH INSURANCE PORTABILITY AND ACCOUNTABILITY ACT (HIPPA) OF 1996
regulations_points.regulation_description: HIPPA limits the collection, storage, processing and sale of protected health information without the consumer's consent. Since corporate wellness services deal heavily with health information, HIPPA is an important law they must adhere to.
COVID-19 forced many businesses to continue their work virtually to stop the spread of the virus, including corporate wellness service providers.

factors_increased_barrier: Labor costs create a significant barrier to entry as employees like data analysts, nutritionists, physical trainers are highly skilled and want to be compensated well.

basis_points.basis_description: Different regions of the United States have separate problems, so corporate wellness services tailor their packages in each area they operate in. Increased specialization makes it difficult for large players to take over the industry, raising fragmentation.

Corporate wellness service providers enter into contracts with large companies, giving them a steady stream of revenue. Small companies that get these contracts are financially stable, so this keeps concentration low.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry's services are tailored to specific regions
Different areas of the United States suffer from different problems
Since local operators have more experience in providing the most specific service, it's difficult for large players to gobble up the industry, keeping fragmentation high.

Wellness service providers enter into contracts with large corporations and other businesses to sell their services for a specific period of time. Large corporate wellness providers can't circumvent the small companies that have already entered into contracts, so this enables concentration to stay low.

FAQs.question: How can your company recruit employers to purchase corporate wellness services?
FAQs.answer: Employers are increasingly focusing on areas other than physical health.

FAQs.question: How can your company promote the use of wellness services in the workplace?
FAQs.answer: Marketing services provided on-site through text messaging is one method of reaching employees.

FAQs.question: How is your company investing in health and wellness budgets and staff?
FAQs.answer: Many corporations have a dedicated wellness staff person.

FAQs.question: What is URAC?
FAQs.answer: URAC is a nonprofit health organization that was founded in 1990.

FAQs.question: How can your company leverage the value of investment in corporate wellness programs?
FAQs.answer: Leveraging health outcomes data following participation in corporate wellness programs can show value.

FAQs.question: Does your company utilize digital technology to improve wellness programs?
FAQs.answer: Employers are embracing digital technology to drive health behavior change.

FAQs.question: How does regulatory uncertainty in healthcare impact your business?
FAQs.answer: The uncertainty of healthcare reform has driven many companies to look at ways to control costs.

FAQs.question: What is the typical profit margin for a Corporate Wellness Services company?
FAQs.answer: On average, profit is consistently below 10.0%.

FAQs.question: Have you considered the return on investment (ROI) for implementing corporate wellness programs?
FAQs.answer: The ROI for corporate wellness programs tends to be positive.

FAQs.question: Does your business have a strong reputation among customers?
FAQs.answer: Employers rely on wellness programs that are recommended through word of mouth.

FAQs.question: How quickly can your company adopt new technology?
FAQs.answer: Successful operators must keep up with the latest trends in software and technology.
